prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for throwing an unwanted party?
So next week is my best friend's birthday and i decided to throw him a surprise party. Everyone was excited and everything was cool untill today.

We talked today just us 2, and i asked him what he is doing for his bday, he said that if said that hes glad theres no party and if there was one he would be mad af. (The party is at his house so hes just gonna be extra mad)

He said he hates birthday parties many times before but i thought he was just saying that so hr won't be dissapointed if theres no party.

Ive been planning this party for a long time and its way too late to cancel. 

AITA for not listening to him and doing whatever i want?
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the person who wrote the AITA post is in the wrong. The situation is about throwing a surprise birthday party for a best friend despite the friend having previously expressed dislike for parties. The friend now says he's glad there's no party and would be mad if there was one, especially since it's at his house.

First, the author planned a surprise party, assuming the friend was just saying he didn't want a party to avoid disappointment. The friend had said he hates birthday parties multiple times before, but the author didn't take it seriously. Now, the author is conflicted because they've already planned it and are too late to cancel.

So, is the author in the wrong? Well, the friend clearly communicated his preferences before. Even if it was a surprise, the author should have trusted those statements. A surprise party can be great, but if the person doesn't want a party at all, it's a problem. The fact that the friend is upset now because he didn't want a party shows the author didn't respect his wishes. Also, the party is at his house, making it even more awkward. The author didn't ask for permission or confirm the friend's current feelings, even though the friend had expressed dislike before. So, the author didn't listen to their friend's clear preferences, leading to the friend's anger. Therefore, the author is in the wrong.
